elements.content: Treatment of poly(terpyridineCuII-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate) with [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] under aqueous basic conditions afforded a new one-dimensional comblike structure with no added Cu; whereas under neutral conditions, a two-dimensional gridlike architecture was formed with newly incorporated metal.
elements.clean_text: Treatment of poly(terpyridineCuII-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate) with [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] under aqueous basic conditions afforded a new one-dimensional comblike structure with no added Cu; whereas under neutral conditions, a two-dimensional gridlike architecture was formed with newly incorporated metal.

elements.content: Treatment of linear [terpyridineCuII polycarboxylate] n with a secondary metal ion (CuI) led to new one-dimensional comblike and two-dimensional (2-D) gridlike architectures with incorporated metal in the 2-D structure.
elements.clean_text: Treatment of linear [terpyridineCuII polycarboxylate] n  with a secondary metal ion (CuI) led to new one-dimensional comblike and two-dimensional (2-D) gridlike architectures with incorporated metal in the 2-D structure.

elements.content: Metal−organic architectures occur widely in nature in such constructs as metalloenzymes and metalloproteins, as well as in the ubiquitous photosynthesis process. An understanding of reaction selectivity and substrate recognition of these materials is critical to imitate their important functions. Tailored organic ligands and transition metals are frequently employed in reaching this goal. In many cases, metals such as copper, zinc, and iron are used as they possess the advantage of usually being the metal used in nature. And, in bioreactions, enzyme active centers, which combine with substrates, usually involve a series of bond assembly and disassembly processes that are mediated by the metal center(s). Crystal engineering has been touted11,15,17 as a vehicle for the construction of bioactive mimics, and notably, 2,2‘:6‘,2‘ ‘-terpyridine-based metal complexes have been used in this regard as well as in molecular devices and antitumor reagents. Herein, we report facile crystal rearrangements to new one-dimensional (1-D) and two-dimensional (2-D) architectures based on the treatment of a terpyridineCuII-pyridinedicarboxylate complex with CuI under basic or neutral conditions, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic architectures occur widely in nature in such constructs as metalloenzymes and metalloproteins, as well as in the ubiquitous photosynthesis process. An understanding of reaction selectivity and substrate recognition of these materials is critical to imitate their important functions. Tailored organic ligands and transition metals are frequently employed in reaching this goal. In many cases, metals such as copper, zinc, and iron are used as they possess the advantage of usually being the metal used in nature. And, in bioreactions, enzyme active centers, which combine with substrates, usually involve a series of bond assembly and disassembly processes that are mediated by the metal center(s). Crystal engineering has been touted11,15,17 as a vehicle for the construction of bioactive mimics, and notably, 2,2‘:6‘,2‘‘-terpyridine-based metal complexes have been used in this regard as well as in molecular devices and antitumor reagents. Herein, we report facile crystal rearrangements to new one-dimensional (1-D) and two-dimensional (2-D) architectures based on the treatment of a terpyridineCuII-pyridinedicarboxylate complex with CuI under basic or neutral conditions, respectively.

elements.content: TerpyridineCuII complexes display a pentacoordinate geometry when binding with carboxylate ions, whereby the oxygen ligands define a perpendicular plane relative to the terpyridine trinitrogen plane.
elements.clean_text: TerpyridineCuII complexes display a pentacoordinate geometry when binding with carboxylate ions, whereby the oxygen ligands define a perpendicular plane relative to the terpyridine trinitrogen plane.

elements.content: Recently, the synthesis and crystal structure of a neutral, linear complex (1, Scheme ) based on the treatment of tpyCuII(OH2)2 (where tpy = 2,2‘:6‘,2‘ ‘-terpyridine) with 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (PDC) under basic conditions were reported; notably, the pyridine nitrogen of the PDC component remained uncomplexed and therefore available for further manipulation.
elements.clean_text: Recently, the synthesis and crystal structure of a neutral, linear complex (1, Scheme ) based on the treatment of tpyCuII(OH2)2 (where tpy = 2,2‘:6‘,2‘‘-terpyridine) with 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (PDC) under basic conditions were reported; notably, the pyridine nitrogen of the PDC component remained uncomplexed and therefore available for further manipulation.

elements.content: Reorganization of crystal1 to 2 was derived by addition of [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] under basic aqueous conditions. (A) The asymmetric unit of 2 (an oxygen atom connected to one of the pyridine-carboxylate moieties has been omitted because it is not part of the asymmetric unit). (B) Structural packing, side view of 2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Reorganization of crystal1 to 2 was derived by addition of [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] under basic aqueous conditions. (A) The asymmetric unit of 2 (an oxygen atom connected to one of the pyridine-carboxylate moieties has been omitted because it is not part of the asymmetric unit). (B) Structural packing, side view of 2.

elements.content: Thus, treatment of this complex with a monovalent metal that would interact with the free site was undertaken. The green-colored crystalline 1 was sonicated in a solution of methanol and water (10 mL, v:v, 1:1) at 70 °C for approximately 1 h or until dissolution. Upon adjustment of sonicated solution22 to between pH 9.0−10.0 with aqueous NaOH, a layer of benzene was carefully placed on top of the solution followed by the placement of a layer of 1 equiv of [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] in methanol on the top of the benzene. After 5 days at 25 °C, blue-colored single crystals (36%) formed at the surface of the methanol/benzene/water mixture. Crystals were also obtained without the use of benzene, although the yield was significantly reduced.
elements.clean_text: Thus, treatment of this complex with a monovalent metal that would interact with the free site was undertaken. The green-colored crystalline 1 was sonicated in a solution of methanol and water (10 mL, v:v, 1:1) at 70 °C for approximately 1 h or until dissolution. Upon adjustment of sonicated solution22 to between pH 9.0-10.0 with aqueous NaOH, a layer of benzene was carefully placed on top of the solution followed by the placement of a layer of 1 equiv of [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] in methanol on the top of the benzene. After 5 days at 25 °C, blue-colored single crystals (36%) formed at the surface of the methanol/benzene/water mixture. Crystals were also obtained without the use of benzene, although the yield was significantly reduced.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analysis (100 K) of the new crystalline 2 (Figure ) revealed a rearranged comblike 1-D structure where one of the carboxylate moieties was no longer coordinated to Cu. The broken Cu−O was replaced by a new Cu−N resulting from Cu coordination with the pyridine nitrogen. Notably, the 1-D structure showed one tpyCuII connected by one carboxylate of the PDC and a nitrogen of another PDC, while the second tpyCuII was coordinated with one carboxylate of PDC and one water molecule. The added CuI did not participate in the crystal growth, although the PF6 - counterions did contribute to crystal formation with two in each asymmetric unit; this is probably due to the formation of Cu+OH- under the basic environment. The Cu−Cu distances in the vertical and horizontal planes were observed to be 7.825 and 8.862 Å, respectively, and distances of 1.919(4), 2.199(5), and 2.275(4) Å were observed for Cu−OOC, Cu−N (of PDC), and Cu−O (of H2O), respectively. The O−Cu−O and O−Cu−N (of PDC) angles were found to be nearly identical at 93.33(17) and 95.61(18)°, respectively. The plane of the terpyridines was nearly orthogonal (87.9°) to the plane of the pyridine moiety.
elements.clean_text: X-ray diffraction analysis (100 K) of the new crystalline 2 (Figure ) revealed a rearranged comblike 1-D structure where one of the carboxylate moieties was no longer coordinated to Cu. The broken Cu-O was replaced by a new Cu-N resulting from Cu coordination with the pyridine nitrogen. Notably, the 1-D structure showed one tpyCuII connected by one carboxylate of the PDC and a nitrogen of another PDC, while the second tpyCuII was coordinated with one carboxylate of PDC and one water molecule. The added CuI did not participate in the crystal growth, although the PF6 - counterions did contribute to crystal formation with two in each asymmetric unit; this is probably due to the formation of Cu+OH- under the basic environment. The Cu-Cu distances in the vertical and horizontal planes were observed to be 7.825 and 8.862 Å, respectively, and distances of 1.919(4), 2.199(5), and 2.275(4) Å were observed for Cu-OOC, Cu-N (of PDC), and Cu-O (of H2O), respectively. The O-Cu-O and O-Cu-N (of PDC) angles were found to be nearly identical at 93.33(17) and 95.61(18)°, respectively. The plane of the terpyridines was nearly orthogonal (87.9°) to the plane of the pyridine moiety.

elements.content: Following the same procedure for the preparation of the 1-D structure 2, with the exception of omitting the base, deep blue crystals (30%) of a gridlike 2-D framework (i.e., 3, Figure ) were obtained from a translucent green solution after 2 days. As determined by X-ray analysis, the asymmetric unit (Figure A) contained one tpyCuII, one bridging CuII (from oxidized CuI), and two PDC groups, in which one PDC bridged the tpyCuII and CuII, while the other supplied its pyridine nitrogen and only one of the COOH moieties for complexation. The second COOH group was uncomplexed and deprotonated affording an overall charge neutral complex. The tpyCuII unit was also coordinated with one water molecule in a typical pentacoordinate fashion. The other CuII connected four PDC units with two N−Cu and two O−Cu bonds; the Cu−Cu distance in the asymmetric unit was observed to be 6.756 Å. The gridlike 2-D framework was constructed by the connection of CuII and PDCs (Figure B). Notably, the tpyCuII moiety did not participate in the 2-D framework but was positioned as a pendant group to a framework participating PDC group. The quadrilateral formed by four CuII ions measured 8.286 × 8.240 Å and possessed 79.81 and 99.38° angles. It is also slightly nonplanar with a 9.68° torsion angle resulting in the Cu chains exhibiting a zigzag pattern (Figure C). The unit cell included numerous water molecules and MeCN solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text: Following the same procedure for the preparation of the 1-D structure 2, with the exception of omitting the base, deep blue crystals (30%) of a gridlike 2-D framework (i.e., 3, Figure ) were obtained from a translucent green solution after 2 days. As determined by X-ray analysis, the asymmetric unit (Figure A) contained one tpyCuII, one bridging CuII (from oxidized CuI), and two PDC groups, in which one PDC bridged the tpyCuII and CuII, while the other supplied its pyridine nitrogen and only one of the COOH moieties for complexation. The second COOH group was uncomplexed and deprotonated affording an overall charge neutral complex. The tpyCuII unit was also coordinated with one water molecule in a typical pentacoordinate fashion. The other CuII connected four PDC units with two N-Cu and two O-Cu bonds; the Cu-Cu distance in the asymmetric unit was observed to be 6.756 Å. The gridlike 2-D framework was constructed by the connection of CuII and PDCs (Figure B). Notably, the tpyCuII moiety did not participate in the 2-D framework but was positioned as a pendant group to a framework participating PDC group. The quadrilateral formed by four CuII ions measured 8.286 × 8.240 Å and possessed 79.81 and 99.38° angles. It is also slightly nonplanar  with a 9.68° torsion angle resulting in the Cu chains exhibiting a zigzag pattern (Figure C). The unit cell included numerous water molecules and MeCN solvent molecules.

elements.content: Structures of the Repeat Units in the One-Dimensional (2) and Two-Dimensional (3) Frameworks Derived from Disassembly of Linear Crystalline 1 with CuI under Basic or Neutral Conditions
elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of the Repeat Units in the One-Dimensional (2) and Two-Dimensional (3) Frameworks Derived from Disassembly of Linear Crystalline 1 with CuI under Basic or Neutral Conditions

elements.content: Rearrangement of crystal1 to 3 occurred by addition of [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] under neutral aqueous conditions. (A) The asymmetric unit (a carboxylate group connected to each pyridine moieties has been omitted because it is not part of the asymmetric unit). (B) Top view of the packing structure (pink balls represent the tpyCuII complex; blue balls indicated in the CuIIPDC complex; the small red spots represent H2O molecules; same structure as 3 in Figure ; hydrogens were omitted for clarity). (C) Side view of Cu chains of the gridlike (CuIIPDC) n plane (i.e., the blue balls in panel B).
elements.clean_text: 2  Rearrangement of crystal1 to 3 occurred by addition of [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] under neutral aqueous conditions. (A) The asymmetric unit (a carboxylate group connected to each pyridine moieties has been omitted because it is not part of the asymmetric unit). (B) Top view of the packing structure (pink balls represent the tpyCuII complex; blue balls indicated in the CuIIPDC complex; the small red spots represent H2O molecules; same structure as 3 in Figure ; hydrogens were omitted for clarity). (C) Side view of Cu chains of the gridlike (CuIIPDC) n  plane (i.e., the blue balls in panel B).

elements.content: A space-filling view of alternating CuII ions and the groups that connect them, along the y-axis of the 2-D structure, (Figure A) reveals a zigzag pattern with a nearly square motif; a view from the top of this pattern shows a slight twist suggesting a potential helicity (Figure B).
elements.clean_text: A space-filling view of alternating CuII ions and the groups that connect them, along the y-axis of the 2-D structure, (Figure A) reveals a zigzag pattern with a nearly square motif; a view from  the top of this pattern shows a slight twist suggesting a potential helicity (Figure B).

elements.content: Crystal structure of gridlike3:  (A) side view of the helical zig-zag pattern along the y-axis; (B) top view of the asymmetric packing (a carboxylate group connected to each pyridine moiety has been omitted because it is not part of the asymmetric unit).
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of gridlike3: (A) side view of the helical zig-zag pattern along the y-axis; (B) top view of the asymmetric packing (a carboxylate group connected to each pyridine moiety has been omitted because it is not part of the asymmetric unit).

elements.content: Rationale for the formation of different crystal architectures 1-D and 2-D under similar conditions, except for pH, prompted the investigation of the disassembly process associated with 1. The green-colored crystalline 1 was sonicated in a solution of methanol and water (10 mL, v:v, 1:1) at 70 °C for 1 h until dissolution. Notably, discernible solubilization of crystalline 1 within a few minutes using sonication generated smaller and simpler fragments derived from dissociation of the Cu−O bonds, which were confirmed by ESI-MS analysis to afford structural insight into the key fragments that further reassemble (Scheme ). Two major peaks were observed in the mass spectrum at m/z 379.3 amu corresponding to fragment 4 (Calc:  C37H25Cu2N7O4 2+ for 379.36) and m/z 461.8 corresponding to fragment 5 (Calc:  C22H14CuN4O4 + for 461.92). Other fragments observed to a lesser extent included tpyCuII and tpyCuIICOO-. Fragment 4 can lead to the 1-D architecture, while fragment 5 can lead to the 2-D grid framework.
elements.clean_text: Rationale for the formation of different crystal architectures 1-D and 2-D under similar conditions, except for pH, prompted the investigation of the disassembly process associated with 1. The green-colored crystalline 1 was sonicated in a solution of methanol and water (10 mL, v:v, 1:1) at 70 °C for 1 h until dissolution. Notably, discernible solubilization of crystalline 1 within a few minutes using sonication generated smaller and simpler fragments derived from dissociation of the Cu-O bonds, which were confirmed by ESI-MS analysis to afford structural insight into the key fragments that further reassemble (Scheme ). Two major peaks were observed in the mass spectrum at m/z 379.3 amu corresponding to fragment 4 (Calc: C37H25Cu2N7O4 2+ for 379.36) and m/z 461.8 corresponding to fragment 5 (Calc: C22H14CuN4O4 + for 461.92). Other fragments observed to a lesser extent included tpyCuII and tpyCuIICOO-. Fragment 4 can lead to the 1-D architecture, while fragment 5 can lead to the 2-D grid framework.

elements.content:
Illustration of the Key Disassembled Components of the Linear Crystal1 a

a  Fragment 4 is the repeat unit of crystal 2; fragment 5 is the repeat unit of crystal 3.
elements.clean_text: 2  Illustration of the Key Disassembled Components of the Linear Crystal1  a        a  Fragment 4 is the repeat unit of crystal 2; fragment 5 is the repeat unit of crystal 3.

elements.content: In conclusion, 1-D linear 2 and 2-D gridlike 3 architectures were synthesized from a solution of crystal 1, which can dissociate into two key components under either basic or neutral conditions. An attempt to incorporate a second metal using [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] was successful in the case of the 2-D structure. The structures were analyzed by X-ray diffraction. The dissociation studies gave rise to a rational explanation for the reassembly process. This method could be applied to the other transition metals for construction of mixed metal complex networks.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, 1-D linear 2 and 2-D gridlike 3 architectures were synthesized from a solution of crystal 1, which can dissociate into two key components under either basic or neutral conditions. An attempt to incorporate a second metal using [Cu(MeCN)4(PF6)] was successful in the case of the 2-D structure. The structures were analyzed by X-ray diffraction. The dissociation studies gave rise to a rational explanation for the reassembly process. This method could be applied to the other transition metals for construction of mixed metal complex networks.

metadata.title:
TerpyridineCuII Polycarboxylate Crystal Reorganization to One- and
Two-Dimensional Nanostructures:  Crystal Disassembly and Reassembly
